I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2000 Country Programming Mission and subsequent consultation missions, 
the Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
for a possible loan to the health sector. This assistance has been included in ADB’s program for 
consideration by the Board in the year 2004. The PNG health sector faces severe problems, 
with key health indicators either stagnating or declining. The goal of the National Health Plan 
(NHP) 2001–2010 is to improve the health of all Papua New Guineans through the development 
of a health system that is responsive, effective, affordable, and accessible to the majority of the 
people.  The  Government  is  committed  to  improving  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  all 
resources provided to the sector. To achieve this objective, the National Department of Health 
(NDOH) is implementing a sector-wide approach (SWAp).1 
 
2.  The ADB strategy for PNG continues to give high priority to poverty reduction, notably 
through human capital development, with basic social services as a significant focus. Thirty-
seven percent of the population lives in poverty, nearly all in rural areas. PNG ranks last in the 
Pacific on the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) human development and poverty 
indexes, reflecting past underfunding of essential services and the difficulty of providing them 
across remote and scattered regions. The situation is worsened by slow economic growth and 
fiscal  constraints.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)2  objectives,  scope,  financing,  and 
implementation arrangements were reconfirmed during a Fact-Finding Mission on 4–23 October 
2002. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB is a long-term partner to the PNG health sector and has supported it since 1982.3 
Several  relatively  large-scale  projects  have  been  implemented  to  establish,  extend,  and 
maintain rural health infrastructure (aid posts, health centers, staff housing) to increase isolated 
communities’ accessibility to essential health services. Support also included rural water supply, 
procurement  of  medical  equipment,  radio  and  communication  equipment,  and  transport. 
Evaluations have confirmed the improved accessibility to primary health care (PHC) facilities in 
many remote parts of the country. However, extending facilities did not solve the problems of 
closure or limited operation of facilities due to shortage of staff, insufficient drugs, malfunctioning 
equipment, and poor maintenance of buildings. Therefore, the real impact of an extended 
network of PHC facilities in terms of increased and continuous accessibility to essential PHC 
services was less obvious and generally not reflected in improved health indicators. The main 
lesson is that extending the health network has to go hand in hand with adjustments in the 
recurrent budget to run those facilities, and with provision of human resources, the necessary 
equipment,  continuous  supply  of  drugs  and  materials,  and  continuous  support  to,  and 
supervision of, the health staff. In short, extending the health network requires a well-functioning 
health system and forward planning of resources.  
   
4.  In March 1997, ADB approved the Health Sector Development Program (HSDP),4 which 
emphasized  performance  of  rural  health  service  delivery,  especially  health  promotion  and

whereby “all significant funding for the sector supports a single sector policy and expenditure program, under 
government leadership, adopting common approaches across the sector, and progressing toward relying on 
government procedures to disburse and account for all funds.”

2  
prevention. Improved sector performance was aimed at increased resource allocation to rural 
health service delivery (including drugs and medical supplies), financial reforms (increased 
hospital revenue from hospital fees), and the introduction of pipeline funding of ADB funds 
through the HSDP Trust Fund Account to NDOH and to all provinces. The allocation of HSDP 
funds to provinces allows provincial authorities to finance priorities in the provincial health plan. 
Guidelines and strict procedures for the use of funds have been developed. Funds can be used 
for all types of expenditures based on priorities stipulated and agreed on in the provincial health 
plan, with the exception of salaries and wages. For the provincial health authorities, access to 
additional funds to maintain and improve service delivery was essential. 
 
5.  The HSDP was a fundamentally new approach for PNG. This approach (assistance 
earmarked to the health sector but focused on agreed-on priorities in the NHP) and financing 
mechanisms (pipeline funding to the level of the health system that is responsible for service 
delivery, be it the province or district) are building blocks of a SWAp to health. As a result of the 
very  good  performance  of  the  HSDP  Trust  Fund  Account,  independently  confirmed  by  a 
management audit,5 this financing and accounting mechanism is now considered by all major 
donors and NDOH as the best financing mechanism to assist the health sector. Australian 
Agency for International Development (AusAID) and New Zealand Agency for International 
Development (NZAID) have joined the same funding mechanism (now called the Health Sector 
Improvement Programme [HSIP] Trust Fund) to transfer earmarked funds to provincial health 
activities, and the World Bank has expressed interest in joining a SWAp based on this model. 
This is a fundamental change in how government and donors do business together. 
 
6.  ADB provided TA6 to the Government for a health sector review to identify modalities 
and priority areas for assistance in the light of experience, and to assess whether policies, skills, 
and  management  systems  are  compatible  with  the  requirements  of  a  SWAp,  should  the 
Government request further ADB assistance for the health sector. The health sector review 
found that despite a coherent framework for health sector activity, as evidenced by the new 
NHP, the performance of the sector over recent years has been mixed. While gains have been 
made in the demographic indicators over the last decade, with an increase in life expectancy 
from 52 years at the 1990 census to 54 years in 1996, the infant mortality rate has risen from 72 
to 77 per 1,000 births. Per capita domestic resources for health have risen by 4% and this has 
been brought about by increasing the proportion of the National budget spent on health from 
4.8% in 1996 to 6.2% in 1999. Compared to its Pacific country neighbors, however, PNG 
spends the lowest proportion of gross national product (GNP) on health and also has the lowest 
level of health expenditure per capita. These overall figures mask significant interprovincial 
differences. While national indicators are poor, some provinces have made significant progress 
over 1996-2001, increasing performance by over 50%. Provincial health administrators of those 
provinces confirm that access to flexible HSDP funds7 have been the most significant change

7 Of paramount importance to the success of the HSDP was the introduction of measures, which established 
minimum performance levels in the provinces as a prerequisite to qualify for continued HSDP funding. This was 
possible as HSDP funding was appropriated at the level of the NDOH. It was under no obligation to provide 
funds to a given province although the objectives of the NHP can be met only through the active support of 
provinces, which, in turn, implement their annual health activity plans. To qualify for continued HSDP funding the 
provinces must comply with the following minimum requirements: (i) Expenditure undertaken is identified in the 
Annual Health Activity Plan and/or is in respect of national priorities; (ii) Only expenditure authorized at the 
decentralized level, as defined in the procedures manual, has been undertaken; (iii) Value for money has been 
obtained on the basis of competitive pricing process; (iv) All original supportive documentation is present and 
filed for all expenditure; (v) Monthly cashbook and bank reconciliation is provided to the HSDP secretariat; (vi) 
Minimum 80 % of expenditure acquitted (balance carried over to next review); (vii) Previously identified issues 
are resolved.

3
over the past years and an important reason for improved performance. The same provinces 
also tend to use more HSDP funds. In short, provinces with adequate capacity to manage 
resources have been able to use HSDP funds to circumvent some of the structural constraints 
of the health sector. 
 
7.  The health sector review concluded that the main area for change is the organization 
and management of the sector, with a strong focus on service delivery. The objectives are to 
consolidate the progress made under HSDP by some provinces, extend the gains to other non-
performing provinces, to institutionalize the management systems put in place at the central 
level, and to increase the efficiency in the utilization of resources. To reach these objectives will 
require strong leadership by the Government to implement the necessary changes, and to fully 
mobilize  the  scarce  management  resources  and  capabilities  of  NDOH.  It  has  expressed 
frustration with the large number of health projects it has to manage, which diverts management 
capabilities away from sector management. The main advantages of a SWAp are increased 
government leadership and control and in the strengthening of systems and capacities. In 
addition, a high level of donor coordination is required in PNG, and the sector-wide approach is 
the most adequate system to ensure this coordination. The test over time will be the outcome in 
terms of real efficiencies in resource use and improvements in health service delivery and 
satisfaction of consumers with these services.  
 
8.  The building blocks for a SWAp in the health sector already exist in PNG. A number of 
significant  reforms  will  need  to  be  needed  over  the  coming  years  before  a  full  SWAp  is 
achieved. Government and donors will have to move from informal to formal joint performance 
agreements, including common management arrangements. The SWAp, as part of a broader 
government-wide agreement between Government and donors, will have to take into account 
overall macro-level agreements, including structural adjustment programs,  public sector reform, 
the  National  Medium-Term  Development  Strategy,  and  the  Medium-Term  Expenditure 
Framework.  
 
9.  These conclusions were presented to government agencies and donors, which decided 
that the Department of National Planning and Rural Development (DNPRD) would set up a 
cross-sectoral working group, with representation of interested key ministries, donors, and key 
stakeholders to formally start preparing a SWAp in health, have a statement of intent signed by 
all interested partners, and define the work that should be accomplished over the next 6 months 
(and  beyond)  to  formally  start  a  SWAp.  The  working  group8  has  met  three  times.  Three 
technical committees (TCs) will prepare and inform the working group’s meetings on specific 
issues.  
 
10.  The Government has requested ADB’s assistance for the TCs and to organize broad 
participatory consultations to prepare the first phase of the SWAp, with a view toward the 
possibility of additional ADB assistance. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output  
 
11.  The  TA  will  help  prepare  and  design  a  sector  development  program,  for  possible 
financing by the ADB, that will enable the Government to introduce and implement the reforms 
                                                 
8 Members of the Working Group include officials from the NDOH, DNPRD, Department of Education, Public Sector 
Reform  Unit,  Department  of  Finance,  Churches  Medical  Council,  Department  of  Intergovernmental  Affairs 
(provinces), donors.

4  
required to improve health services delivery in PNG under a SWAp. These reforms will be 
identified by the TCs, to which ADB will provide TA. 
 
12.  The Government and donors recognize that past approaches are failing and, with the 
deteriorating economic situation likely to worsen things in the near future, new mechanisms are 
needed to improve performance. A number of significant reforms will need to be implemented 
over the coming years to move gradually to a full SWAp in the health sector, building on the 
successes  of  the  HSDP/HSIP  and  the  widely  shared  recognition  that  a  new  approach  is 
required. The TA will assist in preparing the Policy Matrix detailing the program of reforms. The 
Government  and  donors  will  have  to  move  from  informal  to  joint  formal  performance 
agreements, including common  management arrangements through the following indicative 
process: 
 
(i)  government and donors formally agree on a sector plan based on the existing NHP 
2001-2010 as the policy framework for a medium-term strategic plan (or 3-year rolling 
plan). 
(ii) government and donors agree on the most important priorities within the plan, with a 
focus on improving service delivery in the short term, and special attention to the most 
vulnerable communities and people. 
(iii) government and donors agree on what the most effective strategies would be to affect 
sector performance. Agreed-on standards of supportive supervision should be part of 
the  Memorandum  of  Understanding  or  the  Code  of  Practice  and  the  performance 
agreements with provinces. 
(iv) government and donors agree on a realistic resource envelope needed to implement 
those changes (a medium-term expenditure framework [MTEF]). 
(v) government and donors agree on the modalities for resource flows.  
(vi) Government and donors plan to move progressively to common management systems 
and procedures. 
(vii) government  and  donors  agree  on  how  sector  performance  and  progress  will  be 
monitored  (indicators,  sources)  and  through  which  mechanisms  (routine  health 
information system, annual performance review, etc.). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA will help the Working Group prepare a 6-month action plan to put the essential 
elements of the SWAp in place and support the three TCs identified by the working group: 
 
(i)  program, to work on planning and prioritization, and resource allocation; 
(ii)  finance, in charge of issues relating to financial management and procurement; 
and 
(iii)  management, to work on monitoring, supportive supervision, and performance-
based contracting. 
 
14.  Based on the experience developed by ADB through previous projects and in other 
sectors, ADB’s assistance is sought in financial management, procurement, monitoring, and the 
development of MTEF. As regards procurement, the Public Finance Management Act (1995, 
revised in 1999) is fundamentally sound, but procedures in internal management are needed. 
An international audit firm conducted a procurement and expenditure review in 2001-2002 in all 
branches of NDOH and the HSDP/HSIP Trust Account. The firm’s recommendations are under 
implementation. The finance TC will have to (i) identify the need for assistance to the NDOH to 
fully implement the recommendations of the firm, and (ii) propose a methodology acceptable to 
all parties for procurement through pooled funds. The TA will take into account the work already

5
undertaken by ADB and the World Bank on standardization of procurement procedures. The 
use of a private sector procurement agent might be envisaged. The program TC will base its 
work and recommendations on the annual sector reviews of 2001 and 2002, and the health 
sector review. The reforms needed to ensure the successful implementation of the SWAp and 
improve the sector’s performance will serve as a basis for a framework for assistance. 
 
15.  A broad consultation with all stakeholders, particularly in the provinces, will be ensured. 
AusAID has also committed to help the TCs, and discussions are ongoing with the World Bank. 
   
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $630,000 equivalent, comprising $441,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $189,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance the 
entire foreign exchange cost and $59,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be 
financed by ADB on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of 
Japan. The balance of $130,000 equivalent will be provided by the Government through the 
provision of counterpart staff, support services, and office facilities. Detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are provided in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that approval of 
the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. The expected loan amount for 
the subsequent assistance is estimated to be $20 million. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  To ensure the broadest participation from all sectors, DNPRD will be the Executing 
Agency and the lead agency in terms of overall assistance to the Government. NDOH will 
provide office space and counterpart staff and services. The total duration of the proposed TA 
will be 8 months, from February 2003 to October 2003. The TA will require 14 person-months of 
international consulting services, including: (i) a health financial management and procurement 
specialist for 5 person-months, (ii) a health monitoring specialist for 5 person-months, and (iii) a 
health planning specialist for 4 person-months. The consultants will be recruited on an individual 
basis, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Terms of reference are 
in Appendix 4. The TA will provide for a series of workshops and consultative meetings in the 
provinces, to ensure broad participation in the SWAp’s formulation. 
 
18.  With the support of NDOH and DNPRD, the consultants will help the TCs organize and 
conduct  workshops/discussion  groups  involving  provincial  and  local  government 
representatives,  nongovernment  organizations,  churches,  donors,  and  all  other  relevant 
stakeholders.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  1  month  after  TA 
commencement, (ii) a draft final report in June 2003, and (iii) a final report within 2 months of TA 
completion. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000, on a grant basis to 
the Government of Papua New Guinea for Preparing the Health Sector Development Program, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Papua New Guinea (PNG):the Poverty Assessment for 
PNG highlights that Health services are the cornerstone of any poverty alleviation strategy in PNG. Improving the 
availability and quality of health services, particularly in the rural and peri-urban areas, where most of the poor are 
living will contribute substantially to poverty reduction in PNG. 
 
 
B.   Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? Rural poverty is endemic in PNG. The planned impact of the project is to make rural 
services more pro-poor and improve the relevance of budget expenditures for rural people. No specific poverty analysis required.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Three individual consultants will be recruited to carry out the technical assistance 
(TA). The team will work with and report to the Department of National Planning and 
Rural  Development  (DNPRD).  The  TA  will  involve  extensive  consultations  with  the 
National Department of Health (NDOH), as well as other central agencies, in particular 
the Department of Public Management, Department of Finance, Public Service Reform 
Management Unit, Department of Inter-Government Relations, provincial governments, 
churches and other nongovernmental providers of health services, and other donors. 
The  consultants  are  expected  to  collaborate  closely  with  Australian  Agency  for 
International Development (AusAID) and the World Bank. 
 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Help  the  working  group  technical  committees  prepare  the  basic 
requirements for the donors and the Government to move to a sector-
wide approach (SWAp)-based assistance framework. 
(ii)  Help the Government prepare a program for assistance from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 
3.  The health planning specialist will coordinate the work. The consultant will submit 
a progress report to the Government and ADB in May 2003. The team will develop a 
program logical framework/policy matrix and submit it to the Government and ADB as 
part of the draft final report. The TA will identify the adjustment costs of the reforms 
needed  in  the  three  areas  covered.  A  series  of  workshops  and  seminars  will  be 
organized  in  the  provinces  to  ensure  a  broad  participation  of  stakeholders,  from 
governmental and nongovernmental agencies, in the preparation of the SWAp.  
 
1.  Health Financial Management and Procurement Specialist (5 person-
months)

issues relating to financial management and procurement. The consultant will work 
along with the assistance fielded by AusAID and the World Bank on these subjects. The 
consultant’s tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Participate in the identification the required transformation of the HSIP 
Trust Account, in view of a broad participation including both donors and 
Government funds, and assess the potential legal issues. 
 
(ii)  Review the common disbursement mechanisms existing under HSIP in 
view  of  all  stakeholders’  requirements  and  make  appropriate 
recommendations in order to evolve toward a SWAp (restricting notably 
specific geographic or programmatic conditions on disbursements).

 (iv)  Review the HSIP procedures manual in view of the implementation of the

3.  Health planning specialist (4 person-months) 
6.  The  Consultant  will  assist  the  Program  TC,  to  work  on  Planning  and 
Prioritization, and Resources allocation. This work will be based on the Annual Sector 
Reviews (2001 and 2002) and the Health Sector Review (2002). The consultant’s tasks 
will include: 
 
(i)  Project the resource availability for the health sector over the medium 
term (2004-2006) or longer, based on the National Governments initial

ongoing technical assistance/capacity building and how this should be 
met.
